meanings.def: a set of clothes made of the same cloth, including a jacket and trousers or a skirt
examples: She was wearing a grey business suit.
He is dressed in a formal black suit.
They won't let men into the restaurant without a suit and tie.
a two-/three-piece suit (= of two/three pieces of clothing)
a pinstripe suit
He wore his one good suit to the interview.
Two men in suits came out of the hotel.

meanings.def: a set of clothing worn for a particular activity
examples: a diving suit
a suit of armour
His parents had bought him a new suit of clothes for the occasion.

meanings.def: any of the four sets that form a pack of cards
examples: The suits are called hearts, clubs, diamonds and spades.
All the cards have to be from the same suit.
The suit changed to diamonds.
Which suit is trumps?

meanings.def: a claim or complaint against somebody that a person or an organization can make in court
examples: to file/bring a suit against somebody
a divorce suit
His former business associate filed a suit against him claiming £5 million damages.
She plans to defend the suit vigorously.
The company now faces several suits over its failure to protect its employees.
The two companies have settled the suit.
They have agreed to drop their suit against the Dutch company.
a suit against her former husband
a suit over a disputed estate

meanings.def: a person with an important job as a manager in a company or organization, especially one who is thought to work mainly with financial matters or to have a lot of influence
examples: We can leave the detailed negotiations to the suits.
He’s a ‘suit’, not a ‘creative’.

meanings.def: to be a subject that somebody knows a lot about
examples: I'm afraid geography is not my strong suit.

meanings.def: to play a card of the same suit that has just been played
to act or behave in the way that somebody else has just done

idioms.def: to be a subject that somebody knows a lot about
examples: I'm afraid geography is not my strong suit.

idioms.def: to play a card of the same suit that has just been played

meanings.def: to be convenient or useful for somebody
examples: suit somebody/something If we met at two, would that suit you?
If you want to go by bus, that suits me fine.
Customers will be offered solutions that best suit their needs.
He can be very helpful, but only when it suits him.
A variety of dishes were available to suit all tastes.
it suits somebody to do something It suits me to start work at a later time.
Try out the various rackets to find out which one suits you best.
It would suit me fine if I never have to see them again.
This arrangement suited me perfectly.
a shampoo designed to suit all hair types
Choose a computer to suit your particular needs.
Blue suits you. You should wear it more often.
I don't think this coat really suits me.

meanings.def: to be right or good for somebody/something
examples: This hot weather doesn't suit me.

meanings.def: to be convenient or useful for you/somebody
examples: Well, if you’re honest and hard-working, that suits our book.

meanings.def: to be very convenient or acceptable for somebody
examples: This job suits me down to the ground.
Country life suits me down to the ground!

meanings.def: to do exactly what you would like
examples: I choose my assignments to suit myself.

meanings.def: usually used in orders to tell somebody to do what they want, even though it annoys you
examples: ‘I think I'll stay in this evening.’ ‘Suit yourself!’

idioms.def: to be convenient or useful for you/somebody
examples: Well, if you’re honest and hard-working, that suits our book.

idioms.idiom: suit somebody down to the ground
idioms.def: to be very convenient or acceptable for somebody
examples: This job suits me down to the ground.
Country life suits me down to the ground!

idioms.def: to do exactly what you would like
examples: I choose my assignments to suit myself.
‘I think I'll stay in this evening.’ ‘Suit yourself!’
